examples: We upped anchor and sailed away.
definitions.label_groups: transitive , poetic or in certain phrases

definitions.definition: To increase the level or amount of.
examples: If we up the volume, we may be able to hear what he says.
As usual, they've upped the prices for Valentine's Day.
It wasn’t long before they upped him to Vice President.

definitions.definition: To rise to a standing position; hence, by extension , to act suddenly; see also up and .
examples: She was sitting there quietly, then all of a sudden she upped and left.
He upped and punched that guy.
labels: often in combination with another verb
definitions.label_groups: intransitive , often in combination with another verb

examples: 100 new apps and games have just been upped .

main_definition: ( transitive , poetic or in certain phrases ) To physically raise or lift .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , colloquial ) To increase the level or amount of.
( intransitive , often in combination with another verb ) To rise to a standing position; hence, by extension , to act suddenly; see also up and .
( intransitive , archaic or poetic ) To ascend; to climb up.
